TEXT.English: Academia
"It is the mark of an educated mind to be able to entertain a thought without accepting it."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Aristotle, Nicomachean Ethics
TEXT.French: "C'est la marque d'un esprit cultivé qu'être capable de nourrir une pensée sans la cautionner pour autant."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Aristote, Éthique à Nicomaque
TEXT.German: "It is the mark of an educated mind to be able to entertain a thought without accepting it."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Aristotle, Nicomachean Ethics
TEXT.Italian: "It is the mark of an educated mind to be able to entertain a thought without accepting it."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Aristotle, Nicomachean Ethics
TEXT.Spanish: "It is the mark of an educated mind to be able to entertain a thought without accepting it."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Aristotle, Nicomachean Ethics

TEXT.English: Academia refers to an organised community of teachers, educators and researches. The term academia originates from tradition of the classical academy in ancient Greece, especially the Academy of Plato. This early academy was a place where philosophers could teach and their followers assemble and study their philosophies.[PARAGRAPH:2]This ideas was revived in Italy during the 15th century, in particular in Florence and Rome. This new form of academy was influenced by the existing traditions of medieval universities and humanist studies in Christian Europe. Over the course of the 16th and 17th centuries, academies for a variety of fields such as science, linguistics, the arts, the military, literature and philosophy were founded all over Europe, often with the sponsorship of the government.[PARAGRAPH:2]The idea of academia fostered the exchange of ideas and dialogue between people active in these fields and is generally regarded as antecedent to the subsequent development of the scientific method, the modern university and modern forms of research.
Aesthetics

"I believe in the might of design, the mystery of colour, the redemption of all things by Beauty everlasting, and the message of Art that has made these hands blessed."[PARAGRAPH:2]- George Bernard Shaw, The Doctor's Dilemma
TEXT.French: "Je crois à la puissance du dessin, aux mystères de la couleur, à la rédemption de toutes choses par l'éternelle beauté et au message de l'art qui a béni ces mains."[PARAGRAPH:2]- George Bernard Shaw, Le Dilemme du docteur

TEXT.English: Agriculture
"When tillage begins, other arts follow. The farmers therefore are the founders of human civilization."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Daniel Webster, Remarks on Agriculture
TEXT.French: "Lorsque le labourage commence, les autres arts suivent. Les fermiers, par conséquent, sont les fondateurs de la civilisation."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Daniel Webster
TEXT.German: "When tillage begins, other arts follow. The farmers therefore are the founders of human civilization."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Daniel Webster, Remarks on Agriculture

TEXT.English: Arithmetics
"All things are numbers."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Pythagoras

Arithmetic is a branch of mathematics that consists of the study of numbers, especially the properties of the traditional operations between them - addition, subtraction, multiplication and division. Arithmetic is an elementary part of number theory, and number theory is considered to be one of the top-level divisions of modern mathematics, along with algebra, geometry, and analysis.[PARAGRAPH:2]The earliest written records indicate the Egyptians and Babylonians used all the elementary arithmetic operations as early as 2000 BC. The hieroglyphic system for Egyptian numerals, like the later Roman numerals, descended from tally marks used for counting. Early number systems that included positional notation were not decimal, including the sexagesimal (base 60) system for Babylonian numerals and the vigesimal (base 20) system that defined Maya numerals. Because of this place-value concept, the ability to reuse the same digits for different values contributed to simpler and more efficient methods of calculation.[PARAGRAPH:2]The continuous historical development of modern arithmetic starts with the Hellenistic civilization of ancient Greece, although it originated much later than the Babylonian and Egyptian examples. Prior to the works of Euclid around 300 BC, Greek studies in mathematics overlapped with philosophical and mystical beliefs. Greek numerals were used by Archimedes, Diophantus and others in a positional notation not very different from ours.
Alloys
"It is entirely seemly for a young man killed in battle to lie mangled by the bronze spear. In his death all things appear fair."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Homer, The Iliad
TEXT.French: "À un jeune guerrier, tué par Arès, déchiré par le bronze acéré, il convient sans réserve de rester étendu. Jusque dans la mort, tout en lui reste beau."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Homère, l'Iliade
TEXT.German: "So mancher Jüngling fällt in der Schlacht, zermalmt von bronzenem Speer. Im Tode so scheint sein Schicksal vollbracht."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Homer
TEXT.Italian: "Per un giovane è decoroso morire in battaglia trafitto da una lancia di bronzo. Nella morte, tutte le cose sembrano giuste."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Omero
TEXT.Spanish: "Yacer en el suelo, habiendo sido atravesado en la lid por el agudo bronce, es decoroso para un joven, y cuanto de él pueda verse todo es bello, a pesar de la muerte."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Homero

TEXT.English: Evidence of the use of bronze, an alloy of copper and tin, dates back to Thailand in 4500 BC. Several hundred years later, bronze working was discovered in the Middle East. Artifacts from this period show that bronze was initially used for decorative purposes only. This is because tin was not readily available. It wasn't until approximately 2000 BC, when tin was regularly imported from neighboring regions, that bronze replaced copper in the construction of larger items. Bronze was harder and less brittle than copper, and it held a sharper edge. Tools, weapons, and armor made from bronze were also cheaper to produce and more durable. The period of time when bronze was the metal of choice for such items was known as the Bronze Age. The Bronze Age lasted until iron working became prevalent in approximately 1200 BC.
TEXT.French: L'utilisation du bronze, un alliage de cuivre et d'étain, remonte au moins à 4 500 av. J.-C., en Thaïlande. Des siècles plus tard, le travail du bronze a été découvert au Moyen-Orient. Les objets datant de cette période montrent que le bronze était uniquement utilisé à l'origine dans un but décoratif. Il remplaçait l'étain, plus difficile à obtenir. Ce n'est que vers 2 000 av. J.-C., quand l'étain a été régulièrement importé des régions voisines, que le bronze a remplacé le cuivre dans la fabrication d'objets de plus grande taille. Le bronze était plus solide et moins cassant que le cuivre et permettait de produire des lames plus tranchantes. Les outils, armes, et armures en bronze étaient aussi moins chers à produire et plus résistants. La période au cours de laquelle le bronze a été le métal privilégié pour ce genre d'objets est connue sous le nom de l'Âge de Bronze, période qui a perduré jusqu'au développement du travail de fer, vers 1200 av. J.-C.
TEXT.German: Es wird vermutet, dass Bronze, eine Legierung aus Kupfer und Zinn, bereits im Jahre 4500 vor Christus in Thailand verwendet wurde. Mehrere Jahrhunderte später wurde die Bronzeverarbeitung im Nahen Osten entdeckt. Kunstwerke dieser Periode zeigen, dass Bronze anfangs nur zu Dekorationszwecken genutzt wurde, weil Zinn schwer zu beschaffen war. Erst um etwa 2000 vor Christus wurde Zinn regelmäßig von den benachbarten Ländern importiert. In der Folgezeit wurde das bis dahin verwendete Kupfer bei der Herstellung größerer Objekte durch Bronze ersetzt, die härter und weniger spröde war als Kupfer, so dass sich damit schärfere Kanten formen ließen - darüber hinaus waren Werkzeuge, Waffen und Rüstungen aus Bronze auch preiswerter und langlebiger. Die Zeit, in der Bronze das bevorzugte Metall für die Fertigung dieser Geräte war, ist als Bronzezeitalter bekannt. Diese Periode dauerte bis etwa 1200 vor Christus, als das noch hochwertigere Eisen verfügbar wurde.
TEXT.Italian: Le prime testimonianze sull'uso del bronzo, una lega di rame e stagno, risalgono alla Thailandia del 4500 a. C. Diversi secoli più tardi, la lavorazione del bronzo venne scoperta nel Medio Oriente. Gli oggetti risalenti a questo periodo dimostrano che il bronzo veniva inizialmente utilizzato solo a scopo decorativo, questo perché lo stagno non era facilmente reperibile. Bisognerà aspettare più o meno il 2000 a. C. perché, con l'importazione regolare di stagno dalle regioni confinanti, il bronzo sostituisca il rame nella fabbricazione di oggetti più grandi, offrendo anche una maggior resistenza rispetto al rame e la possibilità di produrre punte più acuminate. Strumenti, armi e armature di bronzo erano anche meno costosi da realizzare e più duraturi. Il periodo di tempo in cui si preferiva il bronzo per tali prodotti è noto come l'Età del Bronzo, che durò fino al 1200 a. C. circa, quando fu soppiantato dalla lavorazione del ferro.
TEXT.Spanish: Las primeras evidencias del uso del bronce, una aleación de cobre y estaño, se remontan al año 4500 a. C. en Tailandia. Varios siglos después, se descubrió la forja del bronce en Oriente Medio. Los artefactos de este periodo demuestran que inicialmente el bronce solo se usaba con fines decorativos, debido a que el estaño escaseaba. No fue hasta aproximadamente el año 2000 a. C., con la importación regular de estaño de regiones vecinas, que el bronce sustituyó al cobre en la fabricación de objetos grandes. El bronce era más duro y menos quebradizo que el cobre, y se podía afilar mejor. Las armas y armaduras hechas de bronce también eran más baratas de producir, y más resistentes. El periodo que hizo del bronce el metal preferido para dichos objetos se conoce como Edad del Bronce, y duró hasta el triunfo de la forja del hierro, en torno al 1200 a. C.

TEXT.English: Architecture
"In the architectural structure, man's pride, man's triumph over gravitation, man's will to power, assume a visible form."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Friedrich Nietzsche, The Twilight of the Idols
TEXT.French: "Dans l'édifice, la fierté, la victoire sur la lourdeur, la volonté de puissance doivent être rendues visibles : l'architecture est une sorte d'éloquence du pouvoir par les formes."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Friedrich Nietzsche, Le Crépuscule des idoles
TEXT.German: "In the architectural structure, man's pride, man's triumph over gravitation, man's will to power, assume a visible form."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Friedrich Nietzsche, The Twilight of the Idols

TEXT.Spanish: "In the architectural structure, man's pride, man's triumph over gravitation, man's will to power, assume a visible form."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Friedrich Nietzsche, The Twilight of the Idols

TEXT.English: Architecture is the discipline of designing structures with an eye to specific goals; usually aesthetic appeal, but also functional features such as defensibility. The architect's trade blends that of the ordinary engineer and the artist. On the one hand, all great architecture must be durable enough to stand natural forces and the test of time; on the other, it is often expected to be pleasant to live in and to behold.
Artisanry
"The life so short, the craft so long in the learning."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Geoffrey Chaucer, Parliament of Foules
TEXT.French: "Bien qu'on ait du cœur à l'ouvrage, l'Art est long et le Temps est court."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Charles Baudelaire, Les Fleurs du mal

TEXT.English: As agricultural productivity increased and the demand for specialist goods increased, it became less practical and less desirable to keep control of these industries in the hands of rulers. The invention of currency-based trade made independent life as a merchant or professional easier, especially in urban and semi-urbanized areas. Such trade also contributed to the rising influence of the proto-middle class, and promoted long-range commerce. The availability of rare goods at trading hubs increased, and centers of production where specialist goods were made profited.
Assembly Line
"One cannot walk through an assembly factory and not feel that one is in Hell."[PARAGRAPH:2]- W. H. Auden
TEXT.French: "Il est impossible de visiter une usine d'assemblage sans sentir que l'on est en enfer."[PARAGRAPH:2]- W. H. Auden

TEXT.English: Aviation

TEXT.French: "Ce que le chemin de fer a fait pour les pays du monde, le transport aérien le fera pour le monde entier."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Claude Grahame-White, The Aeroplane

TEXT.English: While the earliest powered flying machines proved useless for war except as aerial scout platforms, the demands of World War One accelerated development of fast, powerful aircraft capable of hauling significant weapons or cargo. Steady improvements in the internal combustion engine, and rapid growth of experience in airplane design, led to a boom in the airplane's capabilities in the 1920s and 1930s. Passenger aviation in planes like the Douglas DC-3 (still in service today) turned aircraft construction into a major industry. At the same time, military airplanes became more powerful and capable, diversifying into fast, agile fighters and bombers capable of carrying tons of explosives hundreds of kilometres into enemy territory.
Ballistics
"Artillery adds dignity to what would otherwise be a vulgar brawl."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Frederick the Great
TEXT.French: "L'artillerie confère un peu de dignité à ce qui ne serait que vulgaire bagarre !"[PARAGRAPH:2]- Frédéric le Grand
TEXT.German: "Die Artillerie verleiht einem vulgären Gemetzel Würde."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Friedrich der Große
TEXT.Italian: "L'artiglieria aggiunge dignità a quella che altrimenti sarebbe una volgare rissa."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Federico il Grande
TEXT.Spanish: "La artillería da dignidad a lo que, de otro modo, sería una vulgar pelea."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Federico el Grande

TEXT.English: The rise of industrial machine tools in the late 19th century had huge effects on the development of artillery. More precise manufacturing meant ammunition that could be fired at far longer ranges, with more predictable fuzing and gunlaying. Advances in metallurgy made for stronger gun barrels and longer range. For the first time, indirect-fire guns were useful for something other than specialist roles. The effective range of artillery increased by as much as a factor of ten within a generation.
Biology
"From so simple a beginning, endless forms most beautiful and most wonderful have been, and are being, evolved."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Charles Darwin, On the Origin of Species
TEXT.French: "Une quantité infinie de belles et admirables formes, sorties d'un commencement si simple, n'ont pas cessé de se développer et se développent encore."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Charles Darwin, L'Origine des espèces
TEXT.German: "Nicht die stärksten Spezies werden überleben, sondern jene, die sich Veränderungen am besten anpassen können."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Charles Darwin
TEXT.Italian: "Non sopravvive la specie più forte, ma quella più adatta al cambiamento."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Charles Darwin
TEXT.Spanish: "No sobrevive la especie más fuerte, sino la más adaptable al cambio."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Charles Darwin

TEXT.English: In finance, a bond is a type of security under which the issuer (debtor) owes the holder (creditor) a debt, and is obliged - depending on the terms - to provide cash flow to the creditor (e.g. repay the principal (i.e. amount borrowed) of the bond at the maturity date as well as interest (called the coupon) over a specified amount of time). The timing and the amount of cash flow provided varies, depending on the economic value that is emphasized upon, thus giving rise to different types of bonds. The interest is usually payable at fixed intervals: semiannual, annual, and less often at other periods. Thus, a bond is a form of loan or IOU. Bonds provide the borrower with external funds to finance long-term investments or, in the case of government bonds, to finance current expenditure.
Calendar
"For everything there is a season and a time for every purpose under heaven."[PARAGRAPH:2]- The Bible, Ecclesiastes
TEXT.French: "À toute chose sa saison, et à toute affaire sous les cieux, son temps."[PARAGRAPH:2]- La Bible, L'Ecclésiaste
TEXT.German: "Für alles gibt es eine Stunde. Und für jedes Vorhaben unter dem Himmel eine Zeit."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Ekklesiastes
TEXT.Italian: "Esistono una stagione e un tempo per ogni cosa."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Ecclesiaste
TEXT.Spanish: "Todo tiene su tiempo, y todo cuanto se hace bajo el sol tiene su hora."[PARAGRAPH:2]- La Biblia, Eclesiastés

TEXT.English: Cartography
"Not all those who wander are lost."[PARAGRAPH:2]- J. R. R. Tolkien, The Lord of the Rings
TEXT.French: "Tous ceux qui errent ne sont pas perdus."[PARAGRAPH:2]- J. R. R. Tolkien, Le Seigneur des anneaux
TEXT.German: "Not all those who wander are lost."[PARAGRAPH:2]- J. R. R. Tolkien, The Lord of the Rings
TEXT.Italian: "Not all those who wander are lost."[PARAGRAPH:2]- J. R. R. Tolkien, The Lord of the Rings
TEXT.Spanish: "Not all those who wander are lost."[PARAGRAPH:2]- J. R. R. Tolkien, The Lord of the Rings

TEXT.English: Cartography is the art of making maps. Since any traveler will do well to have maps of the territory they move through, good maps have been in demand for as long as the art of writing made it possible to create them. Early maps were often crude, with the shapes of continents and the relative position of cities and landmarks grossly distorted. Portions of the map with which the artist was unfamiliar were often decorated with fanciful place-names and the images of fictional creatures, as in the famous "here there be dragons."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Cartography became more of a science during the medieval period, with advances in mathematics and surveying techniques. Growing and spreading populations helped as well - it's easier and more practical to make an accurate map of cultivated fields and townships than of a howling wilderness. During the European Age of Exploration, the art of mapmaking advanced hand in hand with the art of navigation - the one being nearly impossible without the other.
Cement
"A man who builds his own pedestal had better use strong cement."[PARAGRAPH:2] - Anna Quindlen
TEXT.French: "L'homme qui bâtit son propre piédestal ferait bien de choisir un ciment fort."[PARAGRAPH:2] - Anna Quindlen
TEXT.German: "A man who builds his own pedestal had better use strong cement."[PARAGRAPH:2] - Anna Quindlen
TEXT.Italian: "A man who builds his own pedestal had better use strong cement."[PARAGRAPH:2] - Anna Quindlen
TEXT.Spanish: "A man who builds his own pedestal had better use strong cement."[PARAGRAPH:2] - Anna Quindlen

TEXT.English: A cement is a binder, a substance used in construction that sets, hardens and adheres to other materials, binding them together. Cement is seldom used solely, but is used to bind sand and gravel (aggregate) together. Cement is used with fine aggregate to produce mortar for masonry, or with sand and gravel aggregates to produce concrete.[PARAGRAPH:2]Lime was used on Crete and by the ancient Greeks. It is uncertain where it was first discovered that a combination of hydrated non-hydraulic lime and a pozzolan produces a hydraulic mixture, but concrete made from such mixtures was used by the Ancient Macedonians and three centuries later on a large scale by Roman engineers.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the absence of pozzolanic ash, the Romans used powdered brick or pottery as a substitute and they may have used crushed tiles for this purpose before discovering natural sources near Rome. The huge dome of the Pantheon in Rome and the massive Baths of Caracalla are examples of ancient structures made from these concretes, many of which are still standing. The vast system of Roman aqueducts also made extensive use of hydraulic cement.
Ceremony
"Lead them by means of virtue and regulate them through ritual, and they will have a sense of shame and moreover have standards."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Confucius
TEXT.French: "Si le prince dirige le peuple par la Vertu et fait régner l'union grâce aux rites, le peuple a honte de mal faire, et devient vertueux."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Confucius
TEXT.German: "Lead them by means of virtue and regulate them through ritual, and they will have a sense of shame and moreover have standards."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Confucius
TEXT.Italian: "Lead them by means of virtue and regulate them through ritual, and they will have a sense of shame and moreover have standards."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Confucius
TEXT.Spanish: "Lead them by means of virtue and regulate them through ritual, and they will have a sense of shame and moreover have standards."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Confucius

TEXT.English: A ceremony is an event of ritual significance, performed on a special occasion. Even in the earliest societies, religious beliefs were often associated with recurring events that required the performance of ceremonies. These ceremonies could take place in smaller, secluded communities, such as in temples, or in public on squares and marketplaces.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ceremonies often strengthen the solidarity within a society and create a sense of belonging and loyalty to the authorities that were organising them. For that reason, they were often employed by monarchs to legitimise their rule, for example through triumphal marches, coronation ceremonies or complicated court rituals.[PARAGRAPH:2]This complicated ceremonial procedure meant that there was only a limited class of people capable of administering rituals. Over time, this led to the emergence of formal priesthood and organised religion.
Charter
"By these charters, governments were established, magistrates were authorized to act, and laws were enacted for the benefit of the colonists."[PARAGRAPH:2]- William Bradford
TEXT.French: "By these charters, governments were established, magistrates were authorized to act, and laws were enacted for the benefit of the colonists."[PARAGRAPH:2]- William Bradford
TEXT.German: "By these charters, governments were established, magistrates were authorized to act, and laws were enacted for the benefit of the colonists."[PARAGRAPH:2]- William Bradford
TEXT.Italian: "By these charters, governments were established, magistrates were authorized to act, and laws were enacted for the benefit of the colonists."[PARAGRAPH:2]- William Bradford
TEXT.Spanish: "By these charters, governments were established, magistrates were authorized to act, and laws were enacted for the benefit of the colonists."[PARAGRAPH:2]- William Bradford

TEXT.English: A charter is the grant of authority or rights, stating that the granter formally recognizes the prerogative of the recipient to exercise the rights specified. It is implicit that the granter retains superiority (or sovereignty), and that the recipient admits a limited (or inferior) status within the relationship, and it is within that sense that charters were historically granted, and it is that sense which is retained in modern usage of the term.
Chemistry
"Chemistry means the difference between poverty and starvation and the abundant life."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Robert Brent
TEXT.French: "La chimie est ce qui sépare la pauvreté et la famine de l'abondance."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Robert Brent
TEXT.German: "Die Chemie macht den Unterschied zwischen Armut und Hunger und einem Leben im Überfluss."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Robert Brent
TEXT.Italian: "La chimica rappresenta la differenza tra povertà e fame e una vita piena di abbondanza."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Robert Brent
TEXT.Spanish: "La Química supone la diferencia entre la pobreza y la hambruna y una vida llena de abundancia."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Robert Brent

TEXT.English: Civil Liberties
"Give me the liberty to know, to utter, and to argue freely according to conscience, above all liberties."[PARAGRAPH:2]- John Milton
TEXT.French: "Donnez-moi la liberté de connaître, de prononcer, d'argumenter librement selon ma conscience, au-dessus de toutes les libertés."[PARAGRAPH:2]- John Milton
TEXT.German: "Give me the liberty to know, to utter, and to argue freely according to conscience, above all liberties."[PARAGRAPH:2]- John Milton
TEXT.Italian: "Give me the liberty to know, to utter, and to argue freely according to conscience, above all liberties."[PARAGRAPH:2]- John Milton
TEXT.Spanish: "Give me the liberty to know, to utter, and to argue freely according to conscience, above all liberties."[PARAGRAPH:2]- John Milton

TEXT.English: Civil liberties are forms of freedom of action which the state is required to give to all citizens, without limits or with very minimal limits.[PARAGRAPH:2]The idea that one's standing in society confers certain rights is ancien t- most traditional societies grant special immunities to nobles and priests, granting them more room to speak their minds and more confidence of avoiding practices like torture and arbitrary arrest. But in most of the world, the notion that these rights should be universal is relatively new. Similarly, the belief that they should apply without exception even when the state has an interest in ignoring them, as a matter of principle date back to no earlier than the Enlightenment of the 1600s and 1700s.[PARAGRAPH:2]Key among these basic rights are freedom of speech, freedom of religion, the right to vote, and freedom from arbitrary use of police powers. Removing any of these rights makes it far easier for a tyrannical government to suppress dissent, while keeping them in place helps to ensure that the state remains honest, forthright, and responsible in its dealings with the citizenry.
Civil Rights

"I have a dream that my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Martin Luther King Jr.
TEXT.French: "Je rêve que mes quatre jeunes enfants vivront un jour dans une nation où ils ne seront pas jugés par la couleur de leur peau, mais à la mesure de leur caractère."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Martin Luther King Jr.
TEXT.German: "I have a dream that my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Martin Luther King Jr.

TEXT.Spanish: "I have a dream that my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Martin Luther King Jr.

TEXT.English: Certain inequalities have been a feature of most civilizations since the beginning of recorded history, or earlier. Almost without exception, most women were restricted to low-prestige roles as subordinates to men. Many societies identified a ruling elite or 'native' national majority which was free to condemn religious, racial, or other minorities. Large categories of second-class citizens existed in practically all countries, most frequently women, who lacked the political and economic freedoms enjoyed by men.[PARAGRAPH:2]As great increases in wealth, literacy, and access to communications spread through the developed world in the late 19th and early 20th century, this state of affairs was called into question. Women and racial minorities struggled to achieve equal access to economic opportunities and for the right to vote. Ethnic and linguistic groups overpowered and surrounded by foreigners (especially in the Americas and Australia) fought to preserve their right to raise their own children and maintain their language and traditions in the face of intense pressure to dissolve into the mainstream. In recent decades, issues of sexuality and gender identity have sparked much debate and protest between those striving for equality and those that would deny it to them.[PARAGRAPH:2]The battles for these forms of equality, generally known as "civil rights" were one of the defining social forces of the 20th century, and continue into the 21st.
Codices

"Codices, like ancient whispers on pages of bark and parchment, cradle the visions of civilizations, revealing not just history but the sacred dance of ink and insight that connects humanity with the mysteries of time."[PARAGRAPH:2]-ChatGPT

TEXT.English: In the rich tapestry of Pre-Columbian America, codices served as intricate vessels of knowledge, capturing the essence of civilizations through the delicate strokes of indigenous scribes. These illustrated manuscripts were not mere records; they were portals to the cosmologies, histories, and sacred traditions of diverse cultures across the continent.[PARAGRAPH:2]In Mesoamerica, the Maya civilization crafted codices that unfolded the mysteries of their intricate calendrical systems, hieroglyphic writing, and astronomical knowledge. These beautifully illustrated manuscripts, often made of bark paper, encapsulated the intellectual achievements of the Maya, offering insights into their understanding of the cosmos and their complex society. The Aztecs, dwelling in the heart of the Valley of Mexico, also created codices to record their history and traditions. The Codex Mendoza, for example, provides a visual narrative of Aztec life, encompassing tributes, conquests, and social organization. Through vibrant pictorial representations, these codices became a means of transmitting cultural knowledge across generations.[PARAGRAPH:2]Further south, the Mixtec and Zapotec cultures of Oaxaca left behind illuminated codices that depicted genealogies, rituals, and historical events. These intricate manuscripts, blending images and glyphs, became enduring expressions of identity and heritage. In the Andean region, the Inca civilization, although primarily reliant on the quipu (a system of knotted strings) for record-keeping, is believed to have used some form of illustrated manuscripts. Unfortunately, the majority of Inca codices were destroyed during the Spanish conquest, leaving gaps in our understanding of their written traditions.[PARAGRAPH:2]These codices, ranging from the intricate paintings of the Mixtecs to the mathematical precision of Maya glyphs, constituted a diverse library of indigenous knowledge. They were not only repositories of practical information but sacred texts, conveying the spiritual essence of these cultures. The history of codices in Pre-Columbian America whispers through the ages, inviting contemporary minds to unravel the wisdom inscribed on pages crafted from nature's own parchment.
Colonization

"They are very docile and fit for all manner of labor... they are also of quick understanding, and in matters which they have been taught are skilled and accomplished; but they are an ignorant and superstitious people...I assure Your Highnesses that in all the world there is no better people nor better country."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Christopher Columbus

TEXT.English: Colonization constitutes large-scale population movements wherein migrants maintain strong links with their, or their ancestors', former country - by such links, gain advantage over other inhabitants of the territory. When colonization takes place under the protection of colonial structures, it may be termed settler colonialism. This often involves the settlers dispossessing indigenous inhabitants, or instituting legal and other structures which disadvantage them.
Combined Arms
"The whole is greater than the sum of its parts."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Aristotle, Metaphysics
TEXT.French: "La totalité est plus que la somme des parties."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Aristote, Métaphysique
TEXT.German: "Das Ganze ist mehr als die Summe seiner Teile." - Aristoteles
TEXT.Italian: "Il risultato è migliore della somma delle sue parti." - Aristotele
TEXT.Spanish: "Un todo es mayor que la suma de sus partes." - Aristóteles

TEXT.English: Combined arms is an approach to warfare which seeks to integrate different combat arms of a military to achieve mutually complementary effects (for example, using infantry and armor in an urban environment, where one supports the other, or both support each other).[PARAGRAPH:2]The 17th century saw increasing use of combined arms at lower (regimental) level. King Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden was the proponent of the idea. For fire support he attached teams of "commanded musketeers" to cavalry units and fielded light 3-pounder guns to provide infantry units with organic artillery.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the eighteenth century, the concept of the legion was revived. Legions now consisted of musketeers, light infantry, dragoons and artillery in a brigade sized force. These legions often combined professional military personnel with militia. Perhaps the most notable example is the use of light cavalry, light infantry and light horse artillery in advance detachments by France's La Grande Armée during the Napoleonic Wars.
Combustion
"I have always considered that the substitution of the internal combustion engine for the horse marked a very gloomy milestone in the progress of mankind."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Winston Churchill

TEXT.English: An internal combustion engine (ICE or IC engine) is a heat engine in which the combustion of a fuel occurs with an oxidizer (usually air) in a combustion chamber that is an integral part of the working fluid flow circuit. In an internal combustion engine, the expansion of the high-temperature and high-pressure gasses produced by combustion applies direct force to some component of the engine. The force is typically applied to pistons (piston engine), turbine blades (gas turbine), a rotor (Wankel engine), or a nozzle (jet engine). This force moves the component over a distance, transforming chemical energy into kinetic energy which is used to propel, move or power whatever the engine is attached to. This replaced the external combustion engine for applications where the weight or size of an engine were more important.
Community

"We must delight in each other, make others' conditions our own, rejoice together, mourn together, labor and suffer together, always having before our eyes our commission and community in the work, our community as members of the same body."[PARAGRAPH:2]- John Wintrop

TEXT.English: A community is a social unit (a group of living things) with commonality such as place, norms, religion, values, customs, or identity. Communities may share a sense of place situated in a given geographical area (e.g. a country, village, town, or neighborhood) or in virtual space through communication platforms. Durable good relations that extend beyond immediate genealogical ties also define a sense of community, important to their identity, practice, and roles in social institutions such as family, home, work, government, society, or humanity at large. Although communities are usually small relative to personal social ties, "community" may also refer to large group affiliations such as national communities, international communities, and virtual communities.
Companies
"Wealth unused might as well not exist."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Aesop

TEXT.English: A company is a legal entity made up of an association of people, be they natural, legal, or a mixture of both, for carrying on a commercial or industrial enterprise. Company members share a common purpose and unite in order to focus their various talents and organize their collectively available skills or resources to achieve specific, declared goals.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Middles Ages saw continuous advances in financial tools, first in China, but later also in the Middle East and Europe. This enabled more successful organised cooperation between people, even over large geographic distances.[PARAGRAPH:2]Companies were often established to engage in trading ventures or for similar business purposes, especially to facilitate long distance trade. A similar development took place in military organisation: private military companies were established who offered their services to various powers in small and large conflicts. The most prominent examples include Swiss mercenaries and Italian condottieri.
Companion Planting

TEXT.English: In the intricate tapestry of Pre-Columbian America, the history of companion planting unveils a story of agricultural ingenuity woven by indigenous peoples across diverse landscapes. In the absence of modern technology, these ancient cultivators practiced a harmonious dance with the earth, recognizing the interdependencies that could be cultivated between different plant species.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the heartland of Mesoamerica, the Three Sisters planting method showcased a remarkable synergy. Corn, beans, and squash were interplanted, each providing unique benefits to the others. Corn served as a natural trellis for beans to climb, while beans enriched the soil with nitrogen. Squash, with its broad leaves, shaded the soil, reducing weed growth. This trinity formed a sustainable, mutually supportive agricultural system. On the arid plateaus of the American Southwest, the ancient Puebloans embraced companion planting techniques suited to their challenging environment. Corn, beans, and squash, known as the "Four Sisters" when sunflowers were included, created a resilient and interdependent ecosystem that maximized resource efficiency and enhanced agricultural productivity.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the expansive plains of the Midwest, Native American tribes practiced companion planting by integrating diverse crops. Sunflowers, for example, were strategically planted alongside corn and beans, providing support for climbing beans and attracting pollinators to enhance overall crop yield. On the fertile coastal plains of the Southeast, indigenous communities engaged in companion planting by cultivating the "Three Sisters" alongside other complementary crops like sunflowers and tobacco. These practices not only sustained their communities but also nurtured a deep understanding of the interconnectedness of plant life.[PARAGRAPH:2]Companion planting in Pre-Columbian America reflects a profound wisdom-a realization that plant communities, like human communities, thrive through cooperation and symbiosis. These ancient horticulturists, without the aid of modern science, observed, adapted, and cultivated harmonious relationships in their agricultural practices, leaving an enduring legacy in the annals of sustainable farming.
Conservation
"I grow very fond of this place, and it certainly has a desolate, grim beauty of its own, that has a curious fascination for me."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Theodore Roosevelt

TEXT.English: Nature conservation is the moral philosophy and conservation movement focused on protecting species from extinction, maintaining and restoring habitats, enhancing ecosystem services, and protecting biological diversity. A range of values underlie conservation, which can be guided by biocentrism, anthropocentrism, ecocentrism, and sentientism, environmental ideologies that inform ecocultural practices and identities. There has recently been a movement towards evidence-based conservation which calls for greater use of scientific evidence to improve the effectiveness of conservation efforts. As of 2018 15% of land and 7.3% of the oceans were protected. Many environmentalists set a target of protecting 30% of land and marine territory by 2030. In 2021, 16.64% of land and 7.9% of the oceans were protected. The 2022 IPCC report on climate impacts and adaptation, underlines the need to conserve 30% to 50% of the Earth's land, freshwater and ocean areas - echoing the 30% goal of the U.N.'s Convention on Biodiversity. Ultimately, these movements should be further promoted to encourage biodiversity and to conserve a functional ecosystem.
Construction

TEXT.English: Commercialism
"Many a small thing has been made large by the right kind of advertising."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Mark Twain
TEXT.French: "Plus d'une chose insignifiante a pris de l'ampleur grâce à une bonne publicité."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Mark Twain

TEXT.English: Marketing is the practice of persuading people that an object, idea, or behavior is desirable (and worth paying for). Marketing has existed in some form since prehistoric times; one may speculate that the first marketing activities were invented within five minutes of the first invention of commerce. The development of mass media such as broadcast radio, print journalism, and film made it possible to market on a larger scale. The rise of a working and middle class in developed societies with enough disposable income to buy luxury goods made it desirable to do so. The growth of modern industrial corporations that could produce goods in immense quantities made it necessary to do so.[PARAGRAPH:2]Common practices in modern marketing include direct personal approaches, flattery of the customer, praise of the product (intellectually honest or otherwise), and efforts to make the seller appear sympathetic and likeable to the prospective buyer. The main difference is that all these things are now transmitted from the individual advertiser to the mass of the population through new communications technology such as printing, broadcasts, or the Internet.[PARAGRAPH:2]The practice of marketing is often criticized for dishonesty, for misleading people into paying for that which is useless to them, for encouraging people to go into debt, and for discouraging people from thrift and from building up savings for the future. It is also criticized for the increasingly intrusive way in which, in the modern computerized era, marketers use "big data" to analyze individuals' purchasing habits and tailor advertisements to them. This is widely regarded as intrusive, and as having ominous implications for the individual's privacy and control over their own life in the future.
Cultivation

TEXT.English: The Three Sisters are the three main agricultural crops of various Indigenous peoples of North America: squash, maize ("corn"), and climbing beans (typically tepary beans or common beans). In a technique known as companion planting, the maize and beans are often planted together in mounds formed by hilling soil around the base of the plants each year; squash is typically planted between the mounds. The cornstalk serves as a trellis for climbing beans, the beans fix nitrogen in their root nodules and stabilize the maize in high winds, and the wide leaves of the squash plant shade the ground, keeping the soil moist and helping prevent the establishment of weeds.

TEXT.English: People of the ancient world were fascinated and awed by the forces of nature surrounding them. Earthquakes, storms and other phenomena were generally regarded as signs from heaven. Individuals and groups arose to formulate explanations for these events, and pass the knowledge along to the tribe. The priests and priestesses of mysticism, often called oracles, claimed union with the divine through meditation and trance-like contemplation.[PARAGRAPH:2]Oracles across the world developed complex rites and rituals to appease and interact with gods and spirits. One of the most common forms of supernatural power invoked was divination - the ability to foretell the future using signs and portents such as dreams, the motions of the stars, the guts of sacrificial animals, the fracture lines in a tortoise's shell, visions experienced while under the influence of various drugs, and so on. Divination served the common human need to obtain information about the unknown future.
Earthworks

"Earthworks stand as silent storytellers, their ancient mounds and sculpted landscapes echoing the aspirations and spiritual essence of civilizations etched into the very soil they shaped."[PARAGRAPH:2]-ChatGPT

TEXT.English: In the expansive canvas of Pre-Columbian America, earthworks emerged as profound expressions of human ingenuity, shaping the landscapes in ways both practical and symbolic. Across diverse regions, indigenous peoples sculpted the earth to create mounds, embankments, and effigies that transcended mere functionality.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the heartland of ancient North America, the Mississippian cultures etched their presence upon the earth with monumental mounds. Rising from the fertile floodplains, these earthen structures served multifaceted roles-ceremonial platforms, burial sites, and communal centers. Mound-building was a collective endeavor, a testament to the cohesion of societies that wove spiritual beliefs into the very fabric of the land. On the undulating plains of the Midwest, effigy mounds rose like sacred creatures, embodying the spiritual connections of the indigenous people with the animal kingdom. These sculpted forms, often shaped in the likeness of animals or birds, echoed a reverence for nature, a profound acknowledgment of the intertwined destinies of humans and the creatures that roamed the expansive grasslands.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the earthen tapestry of the Ohio River Valley, geometric earthworks unfolded as expressions of mathematical precision and cosmological significance. Circles, octagons, and squares adorned the landscape, aligning with celestial events and suggesting a sophisticated understanding of the cosmos. The earth became a canvas for mapping not just the physical, but the metaphysical. Far to the south, the ancient city of Teotihuacan in Mesoamerica bore witness to the creation of monumental pyramids and intricate urban planning. The elevated platforms and grand structures spoke of a complex society where earthly and divine power converged. The earth was not just a foundation but a canvas for the aspirations of a civilization reaching for the heavens.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the vast deserts of the American Southwest, ancestral Puebloan peoples carved cliff dwellings and constructed intricate stone structures. The earth became both canvas and shelter, a medium for survival and spiritual expression in an arid landscape. Across this diverse tapestry, the history of earthworks in Pre-Columbian America tells a story of civilizations molding the land not just for practical purposes but as a profound act of cultural expression. The earth bore witness to the ambitions, beliefs, and interconnectedness of indigenous peoples, shaping the contours of history with the hands that shaped the soil.

TEXT.English: (Wikipedia) Progressivism is a political philosophy and movement that seeks to advance the human condition through social reform - primarily based on purported advancements in social organization, science, and technology. Adherents hold that progressivism has universal application and endeavor to spread this idea to human societies everywhere. Progressivism arose during the Age of Enlightenment out of the belief that civility in Europe was improving due to the application of new empirical knowledge.
Exchange
"When the Spaniards arrived, the vastness of the land seemed infinite and the treasures beyond all measure."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Pedro de Cieza de Leon
TEXT.French: "When the Spaniards arrived, the vastness of the land seemed infinite and the treasures beyond all measure."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Pedro de Cieza de Leon
TEXT.German: "When the Spaniards arrived, the vastness of the land seemed infinite and the treasures beyond all measure."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Pedro de Cieza de Leon
TEXT.Italian: "When the Spaniards arrived, the vastness of the land seemed infinite and the treasures beyond all measure."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Pedro de Cieza de Leon
TEXT.Spanish: "When the Spaniards arrived, the vastness of the land seemed infinite and the treasures beyond all measure."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Pedro de Cieza de Leon

TEXT.English: The Columbian Exchange refers to the profound and sweeping transfer of plants, animals, people, cultures, and diseases between the Old World (Europe, Africa, and Asia) and the New World (the Americas) that began with Christopher Columbus's voyages in 1492. Initiated by Columbus's arrival in the Caribbean, the Columbian Exchange drastically altered ecosystems, economies, and societies on both sides of the Atlantic. European explorers and colonizers brought crops like wheat, rice, and sugarcane, which were cultivated on newly established plantations in the Americas, while they introduced animals such as horses, cattle, and pigs that transformed Indigenous ways of life. In return, the Americas contributed potatoes, maize (corn), and tomatoes to the Old World, which became staple crops in global diets and spurred agricultural innovation. The exchange also facilitated the spread of diseases such as smallpox, influenza, and measles, which decimated Indigenous populations and altered demographic landscapes. Alongside the biological exchanges, there was also a transfer of cultural practices and technologies, though often these interactions were marked by coercion and conflict. The Columbian Exchange thus set in motion a new era of global interconnectedness, with lasting impacts on agriculture, diets, population dynamics, and cultural exchanges that continue to shape the world today.

TEXT.English: Engine

"Nature, in providing us with combustibles on all sides, has given us the power to produce, at all times and in all places, heat and the impelling power which is the result of it."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Sadi Carnot, Reflections on the Motive Power of Heat
TEXT.French: "La nature, en nous offrant de toutes parts le combustible, nous a donné la faculté de faire naître en tous temps et en tous lieux la chaleur et la puissance motrice qui en est la suite."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Sadi Carnot, Réflexions sur la puissance motrice du feu
TEXT.German: "Nature, in providing us with combustibles on all sides, has given us the power to produce, at all times and in all places, heat and the impelling power which is the result of it."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Sadi Carnot, Reflections on the Motive Power of Heat
TEXT.Italian: "Nature, in providing us with combustibles on all sides, has given us the power to produce, at all times and in all places, heat and the impelling power which is the result of it."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Sadi Carnot, Reflections on the Motive Power of Heat
TEXT.Spanish: "Nature, in providing us with combustibles on all sides, has given us the power to produce, at all times and in all places, heat and the impelling power which is the result of it."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Sadi Carnot, Reflections on the Motive Power of Heat

TEXT.English: An engine or motor is a machine designed to convert one form of energy into mechanical energy. Heat engines burn a fuel to create heat, which is then used to create a force. Electric motors convert electrical energy into mechanical motion; pneumatic motors use compressed air and clockwork motors in wind-up toys use elastic energy.[PARAGRAPH:2]Internal combustion piston engines were tested in France in 1807 by de Rivaz and independently, by the Niépce brothers. They were theoretically advanced by Carnot in 1824. In 1853-57 Eugenio Barsanti and Felice Matteucci invented and patented an engine using the free-piston principle that was possibly the first 4-cycle engine.[PARAGRAPH:2]The invention of an internal combustion engine which was later commercially successful was made during 1860 by Etienne Lenoir. The Otto cycle in 1877 was capable of giving a far higher power to weight ratio than steam engines and worked much better for many transportation applications such as cars and aircraft.
Engineering
"A designer knows he has achieved perfection not when there is nothing left to add, but when there is nothing left to take away."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, Wind, Sand and Stars
TEXT.French: "Il semble que la perfection soit atteinte non quand il n'y a plus rien à ajouter, mais quand il n'y a plus rien à retrancher."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, Terre des hommes
TEXT.German: "Perfektion ist nicht dann erreicht, wenn es nichts mehr hinzuzufügen gibt, sondern wenn man nichts mehr weglassen kann."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
TEXT.Italian: "Un progettista sa di aver raggiunto la perfezione non quando non c'è più niente da aggiungere, ma quando non c'è più nulla da eliminare."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Antoine de Saint-Exupry
TEXT.Spanish: "Un diseñador sabe que ha alcanzado la perfección no cuando ya no tiene nada más que añadir, sino cuando no le queda nada más que quitar."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

TEXT.English: Ethics
"Act only according to that maxim whereby you can, at the same time, will that it should become universal law."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Immanuel Kant, Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals
TEXT.French: "Agis uniquement d'après la maxime qui fait que tu peux vouloir en même temps qu'elle devienne une loi universelle."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Emmanuel Kant, Fondements de la métaphysique des mœurs
TEXT.German: "Act only according to that maxim whereby you can, at the same time, will that it should become universal law."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Immanuel Kant, Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals
TEXT.Italian: "Act only according to that maxim whereby you can, at the same time, will that it should become universal law."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Immanuel Kant, Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals
TEXT.Spanish: "Act only according to that maxim whereby you can, at the same time, will that it should become universal law."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Immanuel Kant, Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals

TEXT.English: Ethics is the philosophical study which addresses moral questions - matters of right and wrong, virtue and vice, justice and injustice. This has preoccupied thinkers since ancient times, but formal discussion and contemplation of ethics as a logic-based endeavour, as distinct from traditions of religious or secular law, are mostly a product of the classical and medieval periods.[PARAGRAPH:2]Different cultures produce widely divergent schools of ethics, ranging from the law-oriented systems common in China to the relatively individualist virtue-ethical schools of the ancient Greeks. Ethics may be highly abstract or applied as a practical matter to questions of professional conduct and personal behavior. They may emphasize the intent of the moral actor, the fulfillment of certain laws and precepts, the consequences of the action itself, or any combination of the above.
Evangelism
"Just as a candle cannot burn without fire, men cannot live without a spiritual life."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Buddha
TEXT.French: "Just as a candle cannot burn without fire, men cannot live without a spiritual life."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Buddha
TEXT.German: "Just as a candle cannot burn without fire, men cannot live without a spiritual life."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Buddha
TEXT.Italian: "Just as a candle cannot burn without fire, men cannot live without a spiritual life."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Buddha
TEXT.Spanish: "Just as a candle cannot burn without fire, men cannot live without a spiritual life."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Buddha

TEXT.English: Evangelism is an interpretation of religion which sees expanding itself as a sacred duty. This view begins with the idea of a specific religion as being at the centre of one's existence. To the evangelist, it isn't simply a matter of appeasing one's own gods, with other people having other gods. It isn't a matter of trying to become personally enlightened. No, this enlightenment must be spread to others, or the reverence of this god must be something that it would be good for everyone to share.[PARAGRAPH:2]Therefore, to the evangelist, the very existence of unbelievers is a disastrous state of the world. It is a crisis facing the souls of the human race, an emptiness in the collective spirit of humanity, and possibly a personal insult as well. Evangelists will go forth and preach to others, converting outsiders to the faith, and to their own specific versions of the faith- by hook or by crook.
Exploitation

"Mine, boys, mine ev'ry mountain. And dig, boys, dig 'til ya drop. Grab a pick, boys. Quick, boys! Shove in a shovel, uncover those lovely pebbles that sparkle and shine. It's gold and it's mine, mine, mine."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Governor John Ratcliffe
TEXT.French: "Mine, boys, mine ev'ry mountain. And dig, boys, dig 'til ya drop. Grab a pick, boys. Quick, boys! Shove in a shovel, uncover those lovely pebbles that sparkle and shine. It's gold and it's mine, mine, mine."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Governor John Ratcliffe

TEXT.English: The natural resources of the Americas have been a subject of exploitation since the arrival of European colonizers. The vast forests of North and South America were rich in timber, and Europeans quickly began cutting down trees to make ships and build homes. The fur trade was another early industry, with beaver, otter, and other furs being shipped back to Europe for use in fashion and clothing. In the 16th and 17th centuries, Spain's silver mines in Mexico and Peru produced vast quantities of the precious metal, which fueled the Spanish economy and helped to establish Spain as a major European power. The Spanish also extracted gold, copper, and other minerals from the Americas.[PARAGRAPH:2]Sugar and tobacco were among the most lucrative crops grown in the Americas, and both were heavily reliant on the forced labor of enslaved Africans. European powers established plantations in the Caribbean and in South America, and vast numbers of enslaved Africans were brought over to work the fields. The exploitation of natural resources in the Americas was often brutal and devastating, leading to the displacement of indigenous peoples, the destruction of ecosystems, and the forced labor and enslavement of millions of people.
Exploration
"One doesn't discover new lands without losing sight of the shore."[PARAGRAPH:2]- André Gide, The Counterfeiters
TEXT.French: "On ne découvre pas de terre nouvelle sans consentir à perdre de vue, d'abord et longtemps, tout rivage."[PARAGRAPH:2]- André Gide, Les Faux-monnayeurs
TEXT.German: "Man kann keine neuen Länder entdecken, ohne die Küste aus den Augen zu verlieren."[PARAGRAPH:2]- André Gide
TEXT.Italian: "Una persona non può scoprire nuove terre senza vederne la spiagge."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Andre Gide
TEXT.Spanish: "Uno no descubre nuevas tierras sin perder de vista la costa."[PARAGRAPH:2]- André Gide

TEXT.English: The earliest intercontinental explorers were part of government-funded expeditions, as with Zheng He, Christopher Columbus, and Bartholomew Diaz. Soon it became clear that there were vast riches to be had from trade in luxury goods with remote lands, and where long range seafaring continued to thrive, private enterprise soon followed.[PARAGRAPH:2]For the people of the time, a trip from Europe to trade for spices, gems, silk and other precious goods in Asia was immensely time-consuming, requiring the most advanced ships and years of time and effort by a crew of skilled sailors. Quite a few ships that attempted the voyage never made it back, being destroyed by storms or hostile locals over the tens of thousands of kilometres of sea voyage.[PARAGRAPH:2]The risks involved created a powerful incentive to limit the financial hazards of the trip - any one merchant who invested in such an expedition might be ruined if something went wrong. Groups of wealthy men began to organize 'companies', bands that would pool their resources and share the costs of the long, immensely profitable trips.[PARAGRAPH:2]Some of these companies were able to secure royal guarantees from their home nations of exclusive trading rights- early examples include the English, Dutch, and French East India Companies. Over time, these organizations became extremely powerful, as the first ancestors of the modern multinational corporation.
Finance
"Banking establishments are more dangerous than standing armies."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Thomas Jefferson
TEXT.French: "Les établissements bancaires sont plus dangereux qu'une armée en campagne."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Thomas Jefferson
TEXT.German: "Banken sind gefährlicher als stehende Armeen."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Thomas Jefferson
TEXT.Italian: "Gli istituti bancari sono più pericolosi di un esercito sul piede di guerra."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Thomas Jefferson
TEXT.Spanish: "Los bancos son más peligrosos para nuestras libertades que los ejércitos en armas."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Thomas Jefferson

TEXT.English: Finance refers to the organized processes of handling money. While money is an ancient innovation, for most of history currency was handled in simple ways. Coins were just another commodity, fixed volumes of precious metal that had some kind of official sanction. A rich person would simply have large numbers of coins, much as they might have a large herd of cattle or a warehouse full of pottery. Anyone who wanted to buy something would simply pile up coins into a large heap that could be exchanged for the good, usually by earning them a few at a time.[PARAGRAPH:2]This had limits. Starting a business, making major purchases or engaging in large scale public works were difficult because the buyer needed to have all their money at once, and at the beginning of the process, in order to accomplish anything. Travel was more dangerous because there was no way to store money during travel except on your person. If you needed money at your destination to do business, you would have to carry it with you.[PARAGRAPH:2]Around 1000 CE solutions to this problem emerged. One obvious solution was the creation of banks - dedicated storehouses that would hold onto money and which could contact other banks in other cities. Instead of traveling with a hundred gold coins on your person, you could deposit the gold in a bank at home, travel to a destination, and 'withdraw' coins from the other city's bank: their records would tell them that you owned the money, but in another place. Banks could also make loans; a large sum of money up-front, to be paid back over a period of time with interest. This allowed the wealthy to invest with more safety and gave the poor an option for buying expensive capital goods.[PARAGRAPH:2]The rise of financial institutions has come with costs. Professional money-manipulators have a great deal of power in society, and sometimes use it at others' expense. But it greatly increases the economic power and flexibility of a civilization.
Firearms
"One man with a gun can control a hundred without one."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Vladimir Lenin
TEXT.French: "Un homme avec un fusil peut contrôler cent hommes sans."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Vladimir Lénine
TEXT.German: "One man with a gun can control a hundred without one."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Vladimir Lenin
TEXT.Italian: "One man with a gun can control a hundred without one."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Vladimir Lenin
TEXT.Spanish: "One man with a gun can control a hundred without one."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Vladimir Lenin

TEXT.English: In its first centuries, gunpowder was too unstable and metallurgy too crude for the new explosive mix to be used for applications other than demolitions, fireworks, and large, heavily overbuilt artillery pieces. But with advances in metalworking in the 15th and 16th centuries CE, it became possible to create man-portable gunpowder weapons, which began to supplement and then to replace earlier ranged weapons such as the bow, crossbow, and sling.[PARAGRAPH:2]By the 17th century, the world's most modern armies relied in large part on blocks of musket-armed infantry, often supported by pike units to keep cavalry from running down the musketeers while they reloaded their clumsy weapons. The pike units were removed entirely with the development of the bayonet, and ever since that era infantry combat has been dominated by the role of the gun and advances in firearms technology.[PARAGRAPH:2]Even though early firearms were little if any deadlier than a good bow on average, they triggered a revolution in warfare. Firearms were easy to learn to use, and incredibly easy to mass produce compared to the cost of a suit of "bullet proof" steel armor. This helped drive the last nails into the coffin of heavily armored shock cavalry in Europe, ended the dominance of nomadic horse-archer cultures in Asia, and triggered a shift towards mass armies recruited from among the populace, ultimately paving the way for the revolutionary levée en masse of the Napoleonic French.
Fortification
"It is from their foes, not their friends, that cities learn the lesson of building high walls."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Aristophanes, Birds
TEXT.French: "Les cités ont appris de leurs ennemis, et non de leurs amis, à bâtir des murailles élevées."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Aristophane, Les Oiseaux
TEXT.German: "Nicht von ihren Freunden, sondern von ihren Feinden lernen Städte, hohe Mauern zu bauen."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Aristophanes
TEXT.Italian: "È dai nemici, non dagli amici, che le città imparano la lezione di costruire alte mura."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Aristofane
TEXT.Spanish: "Es de los enemigos, no de los amigos, que las ciudades aprenden la lección de construir murallas altas."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Aristófanes

TEXT.English: Fortifications are structures built to aid in the defense of a point or area against attackers. Various types of fortification have existed since prehistoric times: the proto-city of Jericho was protected by a wall over three meters high as early as 9000 BCE, although this may have been as much a flood control measure as a military defense. The growth of civilization and advances in the killing power of weapons made fixed defenses ever more important.[PARAGRAPH:2]The basic concept of walling a city is to deter casual raiders and force even a determined army into a protracted, costly siege. Incorporating defensible features into buildings, such as narrow windows and entryways, provides cover to defenders and make it hard for attackers to push into the building safely.[PARAGRAPH:2]Advances in engineering during medieval times, and larger labor forces made available by advances in agriculture, allowed a great increase in the scale of defensive works. Entire provinces could be protected by walls like the famous Great Wall of China, or Hadrian's Wall in Britain. Individual points could be held with great castles and fortresses, strong enough that it would take years of siege to starve them out, as a mass assault by soldiers using normal means was guaranteed to fail.[PARAGRAPH:2]This goal of demanding multi-year sieges became impractical with the invention of gunpowder-based artillery, but the art of fortification remained prominent. Architects devised new ways to build defenses that would absorb and deflect cannon fire, sheltering troops from enemy guns and channeling attackers into zones where the defenders' guns could be brought to bear.
Free Market
"I had to abandon free market principles in order to save the free market system."[PARAGRAPH:2]- George W. Bush
TEXT.French: "I had to abandon free market principles in order to save the free market system."[PARAGRAPH:2]- George W. Bush
TEXT.German: "I had to abandon free market principles in order to save the free market system."[PARAGRAPH:2]- George W. Bush
TEXT.Italian: "I had to abandon free market principles in order to save the free market system."[PARAGRAPH:2]- George W. Bush
TEXT.Spanish: "I had to abandon free market principles in order to save the free market system."[PARAGRAPH:2]- George W. Bush

TEXT.English: In economics, a free market is an economic system in which the prices of goods and services are determined by supply and demand expressed by sellers and buyers. Such markets, as modeled, operate without the intervention of government or any other external authority. Proponents of the free market as a normative ideal contrast it with a regulated market, in which a government intervenes in supply and demand by means of various methods such as taxes or regulations. In an idealized free market economy, prices for goods and services are set solely by the bids and offers of the participants.
Generalship
"Victorious warriors win first and then go to war, while defeated warriors go to war first and then seek to win."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Sun Tzu, The Art of War
TEXT.French: "Le vainqueur triomphe avant même de partir à la guerre, le vaincu part à la guerre puis rêve de triomphe."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Sun Tzu, L'Art de la guerre
TEXT.German: "Der General, der eine Schlacht gewinnt, stellt vor dem Kampf viele Berechnungen an. Der General, der verliert, stellt vorher kaum Berechnungen an."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Sun-Tzu
TEXT.Italian: "I guerrieri vittoriosi prima vincono e poi vanno in guerra; quelli sconfitti, prima vanno in guerra e poi cercano di vincere."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Sun-Tzu
TEXT.Spanish: "Los guerreros vencedores ganan primero y luego van a la guerra, mientras que los perdedores van a la guerra primero y luego pretenden ganar."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Sun Tzu

TEXT.English: In the early ancient world, armies mostly consisted of militia and levies that were only raised in the event of war. These armies were usually small enough and the ensuing warfare limited enough to be directly commanded by their political leaders.[PARAGRAPH:2]During the Roman Republic and later Empire, armies became increasingly professionalised, especially after the Marian reforms. The large extent of the Roman Empire also made it impractical for their leadership to exercise direct control over the military. Similar developments also took place in the Chinese Han dynasty.[PARAGRAPH:2]This development conferred more military and political power to the generals entrusted with military command. While this made armies more professional and successful, it also led to a different distribution of power. In the Roman Empire, generals were often the decisive factor in choosing the next emperor or disposing of an unsuccessful sitting emperor, contributing to the empires instability. In China, competing military warlords ultimately caused the collapse of the Han dynasty.[PARAGRAPH:2]This sort of political power based on military authority paved the way for the idea of nobility in the feudal sense and the system of feudalism in the Middle Ages.
Geography
"Geography embraces the totality of things as the image of the head depicts it in its entirety."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Ptolemy, Geography
TEXT.French: "La géographie embrasse la totalité des choses, de même que l'image d'une tête la représente tout entière."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Ptolémée, Géographie
TEXT.German: "Geography embraces the totality of things as the image of the head depicts it in its entirety."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Ptolemy, Geography
TEXT.Italian: "Geography embraces the totality of things as the image of the head depicts it in its entirety."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Ptolemy, Geography
TEXT.Spanish: "Geography embraces the totality of things as the image of the head depicts it in its entirety."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Ptolemy, Geography

TEXT.English: Geography is a field of science devoted to the study of the lands, the features, the inhabitants, and the phenomena of Earth. The first person to use the word geography was Eratosthenes (276-194 BC). Geography is an all-encompassing discipline that seeks an understanding of the Earth and its human and natural complexities - not merely where objects are, but how they have changed and come to be. It is often defined in terms of the two branches of human geography and physical geography.[PARAGRAPH:2]The European Age of Discovery during the 16th and the 17th centuries, where many new lands were discovered and accounts by European explorers such as Christopher Columbus, Marco Polo, and James Cook revived a desire for both accurate geographic detail, and more solid theoretical foundations in Europe.[PARAGRAPH:2]The 18th and the 19th centuries were the times when geography became recognized as a discrete academic discipline, and became part of a typical university curriculum in Europe (especially Paris and Berlin).
Geology
"Man, a mere inhabitant of the earth, cannot overstep its boundaries! But though he is confined to its crust, he may penetrate into all its secrets."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Jules Verne, The Steam House
TEXT.French: "L'homme, simple habitant de la terre, ne saurait en franchir les bornes ! Mais s'il est rivé à son écorce, il peut en pénétrer tous les secrets."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Jules Verne, La Maison à vapeur
TEXT.German: "Man, a mere inhabitant of the earth, cannot overstep its boundaries! But though he is confined to its crust, he may penetrate into all its secrets."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Jules Verne, Journey to the Center of the Earth
TEXT.Italian: "Man, a mere inhabitant of the earth, cannot overstep its boundaries! But though he is confined to its crust, he may penetrate into all its secrets."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Jules Verne, Journey to the Center of the Earth
TEXT.Spanish: "Man, a mere inhabitant of the earth, cannot overstep its boundaries! But though he is confined to its crust, he may penetrate into all its secrets."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Jules Verne, Journey to the Center of the Earth

TEXT.English: The word geology comes from Greek, meaning "knowledge of the earth." Throughout history, humans have searched for mineral resources valuable to them; the best flint and obsidian for toolmaking, veins of gold, silver, and gems, the ores of useful metals. The systematic rise of science in the 18th century, and the relaxation of old taboos about the nature and origin of the world, allowed scholars to think more freely about the earth, as about other subjects. These 'geologists' examined rock strata, tectonic activity such as earthquakes and volcanoes, and the patterns formed in the landscape by erosion and other forces of nature.[PARAGRAPH:2]In doing so, they replaced the old, naive picture of the world as an unchanging mass of rock. Geologists of the 19th and 20th centuries have learned that the ground we stand on is actually a series of plates of stone floating on the sea of lava that makes up most of the Earth's mass. Over the eons ("geologic time") powerful forces slowly reshape the landscape, bringing new rock closer to the surface and rearranging the terrain to form mountains and seas.[PARAGRAPH:2]Understanding geology helps us understand where to find mineral resources, and how to channel the elemental forces of earth and water to our advantage.
Globalism
"I am a citizen of the world."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Diogenes of Sinope
TEXT.French: "Je suis citoyen du monde."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Diogène de Sinope
TEXT.German: "I am a citizen of the world."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Diogenes of Sinope
TEXT.Italian: "I am a citizen of the world."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Diogenes of Sinope
TEXT.Spanish: "I am a citizen of the world."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Diogenes of Sinope

TEXT.English: Globalization is the process by which different peoples spread across the world become united by ties of ideology, economics, and politics. The first wave of globalization took place during the 19th century Age of Imperialism, when steam power and telegraphy allowed European empires to spread zones of influence across most of the world, creating a web of transport, communication, and government. However, access to these networks was limited and patchy and many people neither knew nor cared about events in far-off lands.[PARAGRAPH:2]The World Wars sped up the process. The staggering, apocalyptic scale of combat caught up many colonial possessions in Africa and Asia, permanently undermining European rule at the same time that people in economic backwaters were exposed to a wide variety of modern products and weapons. After World War Two, ideologies such as nationalism or communism spread into regions that had previously been dominated by traditional cultures that were less inclined to resist foreign rule. A wave of "decolonization" swept the world.[PARAGRAPH:2]But this was not the end. Direct imperial rule of poor nations by rich ones went out of fashion, the economic bonds between rich and poor were not so easily broken. The industrial giants of the developed world could easily produce enough goods to supply massive export markets, while needing to import raw materials on an ever-growing scale as their own supplies of timber, coal, ore, and oil became depleted. Along with these flows of goods came flows of popular products and the culture that came with them, particularly from the United States. Artifacts of American culture (Hollywood movies, blue jeans, Coca-Cola) became world-spanning; to a lesser extent this diffusion worked from other sources, and even worked the other way, with foreign customs being adopted in the former colonial metropoles.[PARAGRAPH:2]Along with these economic ties came an entangled world political stage. Dictators of small, remote countries could no longer count on isolation and control of the media to keep their people from becoming restless, or to keep large foreign powers from intruding on their business. The only security for small nations was to align themselves with the economic interests of the great power blocs, supplying cheap resources and labor and giving themselves a place in the new world order.[PARAGRAPH:2]Today the world is extensively globalized, a product of the capitalist triumph of the post-Cold War era. Whether this is socially desirable, economically sustainable, or even ecologically survivable remains to be seen, and is likely to become one of the great questions of the 21st century.
Officials
"It is my hope that, through your good example, the settlement of Georgia may prove a blessing and not a curse to the native inhabitants."[PARAGRAPH:2]- James Oglethorpe
TEXT.French: "It is my hope that, through your good example, the settlement of Georgia may prove a blessing and not a curse to the native inhabitants."[PARAGRAPH:2]- James Oglethorpe
